div.h1: Digital tools in the humanities: Some fundamental provocations?

div.div: Department of Digital Humanities, King's College London, London, UK
Correspondence: John Bradley, Department of Digital Humanities, King's College London, Room G04, Norfolk Building, Strand Campus, WC2R 2LS, London. E-mail:john.bradley@kcl.ac.uk
Search for other works by this author on:
Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 34, Issue 1, April 2019, Pages 13–20, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqy033

div.p: John Bradley, Digital tools in the humanities: Some fundamental provocations?, Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 34, Issue 1, April 2019, Pages 13–20, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqy033

p.em: (Attributed to Benjamin Franklin by Samuel Johnson)

div.p: Although digital tools built by those outside the Digital Humanities (DH) community (particularly tools for big data analysis or social network analysis) currently take a significant amount of DH attention these days, there has been toolmaking inside the DH for about 70 years. This article’s author has acted as a tool developer from time to time over many years, and this work has been part of his personal experience of DH from the 1970s to the present day (some history of his involvement in DH can be found in Bradley and Nylan, 2016). Text Analysis...
